data.title: Tech Report (June 17, 1998)
data.text:
Issue date: June 17, 1998

Tech Report Tech Report (June 17, 1998)

Following is news from technology and venture capital companies in Almanmac communities. Dell'Oro Group in Portola Valley reports that total sales of shared hubs and local-area network (LAN) switches grew 3 percent to $2.4 billion in 1998. Port shipments grew 7 percent to $28 million. The report contains tables of data on the performance of over 20 manufacturers. The Dell'Oro Group is a research and consulting firm specializing in business planning in the networking industry.

JetFax of Menlo Park reports that Gestetner Group, a London-based supplier of document-processing products, is now bundling a copy of JetFax's PaperMaster software with its multifunction peripheral products, which print, fax, copy, and scan documents. PaperMaster software helps users store and organize documents electronically on a PC rather than as hardcopy in a filing cabinet.

Nuance Communications of Menlo Park, a supplier of speech recognition software for self-service transactions and network applications, has introduced Nuance SpeechObjects, a set of reusable components incorporating design and development standards to "significantly speed up development of speech-enabled applications," the company said. Nuance develops speech recognition software to automate access to information and services over the phone. The company focuses on customer service applications in call centers, particularly within the financial services and travel industries. For more information, check www.nuance.com.

Informix Corp. of Menlo Park, a database software company, reports that Sporting News Online, an Internet sports site and winner of the 1998 National Magazine Award for general excellence in new media, uses Informix technology as the backbone of a system that automates the web publishing process. The Informix system provides editorial staff members with instant access to a library of images, audio clips and text, and relieves them of complex tasks involved in storing and locating images and preparing them for publishing on web sites where The Sporting News is syndicated, said John Bartlett, director of web product marketing at Informix. The web address is www.sportingnews.com.

Release Software of Menlo Park, a company that distributes software over the Internet, has signed an agreement with World Opponent Network (WON) of Bellevue, Wash., that gives Release electronic and boxed software distribution rights on the WON Internet site (www.won.net), and gives WON access to Release's software library of 3,000 digital and boxed titles. Under the agreement, Release will operate an online software store (www.gamegang.com) where users can buy games and entertainment software that can be downloaded or shipped, said Matthew Klein, president of Release Software.

Homestead Technologies Inc. of Menlo Park reports its has completed a $4.5 million round of financing from a group led by Draper Fisher Jurvetson, a venture capital firm. Homestead will soon introduce Homestead.com, a service that allows users -- from friends and families to schoolmates, clubs and small businesses -- to collaboratively create and publish on the Web without using software or learning to program, said Justin Kitch, CEO and founder of Homestead. "Homestead makes interacting on the Web as easy as making a phone call or writing a letter," said Tim Draper, founder of Draper Fisher Jurvetson. Founded in 1997, Homestead has about 50 employees.

SRI International, the research and consulting firm based in Menlo Park, has named Bill Mark vice president of its Information and Computing Sciences Division. He comes from National Semiconductor where he served as director of the architecture laboratory; he also worked for Lockheed Martin Palo Alto Research Labs. Dr. Mark is charged with expanding SRI's information technology business, opening up new areas of research and applications, and increasing efforts to build commercial business, said William P. Sommers, president and CEO of SRI International. The Information and Computing Sciences Division develops technologies in speech, information security, formal verification and machine intelligence.

Dain Rauscher Wessels of Portola Valley is among managing underwriters of an initial public offering for Multex Systems Inc. Multex provides online investment research for institutional investors, investment banks, brokerage firms, corporations and individual investors. A written prospectus relating to the offering may be obtained from Dain Rauscher Wessels, 3280 Alpine Road, Portola Valley, CA 94028.

Informix Corp. of Menlo Park, a database software company, has announced it will distribute free its Informix Dynamic Server database software to Windows NT developers. "We want to aggressively stimulate the development of NT applications on the Informix database platform," said Joe Niemann, vice president of Channels, Informix. For more information, check www.informix.com.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------- END file sent 6-5-98 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
